text: Jiří Stránský (12 August 1931 – 29 May 2019) was a Czech author, playwright, translator, political prisoner during the country's communist regime, and human rights activist. In 1953, he was arrested by the communists and sentenced to eight years of forced labor for "treason". He was released in 1960. In 1974, he was arrested again and sentenced to another 3 to 5 years, but was released after one and a half. After the fall of the communist regime, he was an author and head of the international section of the Czech Literary Fund. In 1992, he was elected President of the Czech section of International PEN. He was chairman of the council of the National Library from 1995 to 1998. He was a founding signatory of the Prague Declaration on European Conscience and Communism. Stránský died on 29 May 2019 at the age of 87. == Works == * Za plotem, written in prison (1953–1960), published 1999 * Štěstí, 1969, most copies were confiscated and destroyed by the communists, it was released in 1990 * Zdivočelá země, 1970, made into a film in 1997 * Aukce, 1997, sequel Zdivočelé země, 1989 * Přelet, 2001 * Povídačky pro moje slunce, 2002 * Tichá pošta, 2002 * Povídačky pro Klárku, 2004 * Perlorodky, 2005 * Srdcerváč, 2005 * Stařec a smrt, 2007 === Short stories === * Náhoda, 1976 * Vánoce, 1976 * Přelet, 1976 * Oblouk, 2009 * Dopisy bez hranic (Lasica, Stránský), 2010 === Films based on his work === * Bumerang, 1996, directed by Hynek Bočan * Zdivočelá země, 1997 * Zdivočelá země, series 1997–2001, directed by Hynek Bočan * Uniforma, 2001, directed by Hynek Bočan * Žabák, 2001, directed by Hynek Bočan * Kousek nebe, 2005, directed by Petr Nikolaev ==References== ==Other websites== * Category:Czech poets Category:Czech novelists Category:Czech playwrights Category:Czech human rights activists Category:Czechoslovak anti-communists Category:1931 births Category:2019 deaths Category:Czech screenwriters Category:Czech translators Category:Writers from Prague
